Dehydration of isopropanol to propylene over fullerene[C60] containing niobium phosphate catalyst: Study on catalyst recyclability Anindya Ghosh a Kushanava Bhaduri a Sneha Shah a Aline Auroux b J.K. Pandey c Biswajit Chowdhury a ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines), Dhanbad, Jharkhand, India Department of Applied Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines) Dhanbad Jharkhand India b Institut de recherches sur la catalyse et l'environnement de Lyon (IRCELYON), UMR 5256 CNRS- Université Lyon1, 2 avenue Albert Einstein, 69626, Villeurbanne Cedex, France Institut de recherches sur la catalyse et l'environnement de Lyon (IRCELYON) UMR 5256 CNRS- Université Lyon1, 2 avenue Albert Einstein Villeurbanne Cedex 69626 France c Central Institute of Mining and Fuel research, Brawa Road, Dhanbad, India Central Institute of Mining and Fuel research Brawa Road Dhanbad India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Synthesis of lower olefins from biomass is an attractive area of research as the petroleum feedstocks are limited day to day. A fullerene [C60] based niobium phosphate acid catalyst has been tested for isopropanol dehydration in gas phase for production of propylene and a thorough study has been undertaken on its recyclability. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst before and after reaction have been studied by several techniques, namely FTIR, FESEM, BET surface area, HRTEM, NH3-TPD, TGA, XRD and O2-TPO. The BET result suggests the trapping of coke within the micropores which retard the catalytic activity. Interestingly, the NH3-TPD profile demonstrates the abrupt increase in acidity of the used catalyst due to the widening of narrow pores while, CP-MAS 31 P NMR spectra show increase in population of hydrogen phosphate species may be caused by the decomposition of surfactant phosphoric acid complex. However, the UV–vis spectra support structural change by the oxidation of fullerene during regeneration leads to decrease in the acidity. The catalytic activity is evaluated in the temperature range 453–573 K, shows consistent performance up to 6th regenerated cycle with low activation energy (30 ± 5 kJ/mol). Furthermore, a detailed discussion of the reaction kinetics and reaction mechanism has also been demonstrated. Keywords Coke Fullerene oxidation Isopropanol Dehydration Niobium phosphate 1 Introduction Lower olefins are main constituents in the chemical industry and their demand is rising day by day due to their diverse commercial market (packing materials, solvents, anti-freezing agents, synthetic fibers, etc.) [1]. Conventionally, lower olefins are obtained from highly energy demanding processes such as steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking of petroleum feedstock [2,3]. So, finding alternative and environment-friendly process for the production of lower olefins has gained considerable interest to replace the limited abundance of petroleum feedstock. In this connection, short chain alcohols (methanol, ethanol, butanol, isopropanol, etc.) to olefin is the best choice within the scientific community as they can be produced easily from a multifarious natural source like coal, biomass and natural gas. It is well known that the acidic zeolite and zeotype catalysts are the potential candidate for the conversion of methanol or ethanol to olefins reaction [2–6]. The product selectivity and catalyst stability (coke resistance, hydrothermal stability, and long activity) are the major issues in these processes because reaction occurs within the micropores of the zeolite framework [2,5]. Thus, apart from acidity and thermal stability, cage topology is also crucial in order to avoid both diffusion problem and improper product distributions. SAPO-34 catalyst molecular sieve has been recognized as a commercial catalyst for MTO reaction due to its mild acidity, thermal stability and unique cages with 8th ring opening (0.38 × 0.38 nm) [3,6,7]. However, ZSM-5 based catalyst is well known for the ethanol to lower olefin conversion [2,8]. Besides alcohol to olefins, there are many other methods developed so far for the synthesis of olefins e.g. FTO (Fischer-Tropsch to olefin) process [9,10], DMTO (Dimethyl ethyl ether to olefin) process, CO2 to olefin [11], ETH (Ethanol to hydrocarbon) process [12,13] but all have a common problem of catalyst deactivation. A continuous attention has been given towards the investigation on catalyst deactivation as it is the basic parameter for catalyst commercialization. There are various reasons related to catalyst deactivation such as reaction temperature, sintering, change of location of active centers, pore structure, acidic and textural properties, reactant nature, less desorption of formed products, etc. [12]. Depending on the reason of catalyst deactivation, several methodologies were adopted to avoid immediate deactivation. Wang et al. observed that the physically blended SAPO-34 with MgO significantly decrease coke formation for MTO reaction due to opening of parallel reaction pathway through oxygenated intermediates [6]. Lakiss et al. suggested that the creation of macro or mesopores and reduction of zeolite crystal size can reduce the coke formation for ETH reaction, as the number of pore mouth increases and diffusion path length decreases [13]. Recently, Huang et al. proposed that the incorporation of Zn species inside SAPO-34 channel increases ethane to propane ratio by enhancing the diffusion hindrance for MTO reaction [3]. Therefore, a thorough understanding of the reason behind the catalyst deactivation is always needed from fundamental scientific point of view. Dehydration of alcohol over an acidic catalyst is another significant reaction for the easy production of value-added alkenes (propylene, ethylene) and ethers, through intra-molecular and inter-molecular path [14,15]. Metal phosphate has gained considerable attention for dehydration reaction among various active catalysts such as zeolites, mixed oxides, supported heteropolyacids [16–18]. Metal phosphates are also used in different reactions such as alkylation, isomerization, esterification for their excellent acidity and thermal stability [19–21]. Niobium phosphate shows catalytic activity towards phenol hydroxylation, Friedel-craft alkylation, fructose dehydration, fatty acid esterification reaction, etc. [22–25]. The acidic strength of the metal phosphate can be changed either by introducing different metal ions, or by changing the metal and phosphate ratio or by changing the preparation condition [26]. From a mechanistic point of view, the dehydration of isopropanol is catalyzed by an acidic site. As a consequence, the dehydration rate is regarded as the measure of the acidity of the catalyst. Dehydration of isopropanol to propylene has been widely performed on different catalysts such as mixed oxides, zeolites, heteropolyacids [17,27–29]. Propylene is one of the most important chemical intermediates for the production of valuable polymers [30,31] and other bulk chemical derivatives [32]. Every year, the increase in demand of polypropylene (64%), propylene oxide (7%), acrylonitrile (10%), oxo alcohol (9%) and others (10%) [33] increases the growth rate of propylene by 4–5% worldwide. To replace the limited abundance of petroleum feedstock, finding an alternative route for the production of propylene from biomass is a great challenge [1]. In order to get alkene as a dehydrated product from alcohol, acidic or both acidic and basic catalytic environment is required [27,34]. Aramendía et al. reported magnesium oxide as a basic catalyst for isopropanol decomposition but dehydrogenation is predominant over dehydration reaction [35]. Wang et al. found 98.3% conversion and 100% propylene selectivity at 573 K, where Brönsted acid sites are situated within the framework channel of gallium borate [36]. Higher acidity leads to deposition of carbonaceous species on the surface of the catalyst that causes immediate deactivation. Coq et al. reported Pt/SiO2-C60 catalyst for liquid phase hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde, where fullerene favors the orientation of the phenyl ring to make the reaction feasible [37]. Braun et al. has also studied hydrogenation of CO and cyclohexanone on fullerene-based ruthenium catalyst at moderate and low temperature [38]. To the best of our knowledge, our group was the first to report, fullerene containing niobium phosphate solid acid catalyst for dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene in the gas phase. It was also reported that deposited coke is responsible for decreasing the activity of the catalyst after few hours of reaction time [39]. A systematic optimization was studied by variation calcination temperature, niobium and phosphorous contents and corelated with their textural and chemical properties of the catalyst. In this work we aimed to investigate the deactivation and regeneration of fullerene containing niobium phosphate catalyst for isopropanol dehydration reaction. As the catalyst comprises of nanostructured carbon in the form of fullerene so the formation of soft carbon layer due to propylene oligomerization could change the physicochemical properties during regeneration keeping the property of original catalyst as such. The catalyst is well characterized after the reaction and regeneration by several characterization techniques such as FTIR, FESEM, BET, NH3-TPD, HRTEM, TGA, XRD and O2-TPO. A correlation has also been shown in between the catalytic activity, chemical property structural as well as textural property of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents CTAB (N-Cetyl-N,N,N-Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide M.W = 364.45, Loba Chemie, 98%). Phosphoric acid (Alfa Aesar, 85% aq. Solution), Niobium Pentachloride (Sigma Aldrich, 99%), Isopropanol (SRL, 99.5%) and Ethanol (Changshu Yanyuan Chemical China) were purchased and further used without any purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation and catalytic activity testing The catalyst was prepared by one-pot Sol-Gel EISA method as reported by our group [39], having a fixed molar composition 1Nb: 3P: 0.5CTAB followed by drying at 338 K for 48 h and finally calcined at 673 K in muffle furnace (Thermcraft, USA). The performance of the catalysts was evaluated in isopropanol dehydration at atmospheric pressure at a wide range of temperature (453–573 K) using fixed bed reactor, where 0.5 g catalyst containing quartz glass tube reactor was positioned in the electrically heated furnace of the fixed bed reactor. A thermocouple was placed to monitor temperature. Before starting the reaction, the loaded catalyst was pretreated at a temperature 673 K for 1 h with N2 (purity 99.999%) at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. Then reaction was started by introducing the reactant (isopropanol) through syringe pump (B Braun) at a WHSV 4.7 h−1. The regeneration of the catalyst was done by flowing N2 and O2 mixture with 3:7 vol ratio to achieve the total flow rate 30 mL/min at 623 K for 1 h. The fresh catalyst was named as fNP13 whereas used and regenerated catalysts were denoted as uNP13 and rNP13 respectively. The products were analyzed by online gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B) with HP-FFAP capillary column (30m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) using FID detector (temperature program: 333 K (4 min)-20 K/min-473 K). To avoid condensation a heated jacket line was connected in between gas chromatography and the fixed bed reactor. 2.3 Characterization The BET surface area and porosity analysis of the fresh, used and regenerated samples were carried out at liquid nitrogen temperature with VSAP 2020 micromeritics at 77 K. Prior to analysis, the catalysts were degassed at high vacuum at 573 K for 3 h. X-Ray diffraction analysis was done by using Rigaku Ultima 4 diffractometer under operating conditions at 40 kV voltage and 40 mA currents. The calibration was carried out by standard silicon sample using Ni-filtered (Cu K = 0.15406 nm) radiation. A Supra 55, Carl (Zeiss, Germany) microscope having an oxford instrument X-max detector and a Gemini beam line attachment was used for FESEM and EDAX analysis. All Samples were supported on lacey carbon and then coated with gold by plasma before the measurement. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were captured by Jeol/JEM 2100 instruments operated at a voltage of 200 KV. TGA analysis was carried on Mettler Toledo instruments by flowing of air at a temperature ramp 100 C/min. The O2-TPO analysis was performed on ChemiSorb 2750 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) with a TCD detector. At first the catalysts were pretreated at 373 K for 1 h by He (99.999%) gas then the spectra were recorded by flowing of O2/Ar (5%) in the temperature range 373–1073 K. The ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) technique was conducted by ChemiSorb 2750 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) using TCD detector. Around 200 mg sample was activated with He (99.999%) gas at 673 K for 1 h and prior to the experiment, NH3 was adsorbed at room temperature by flowing of NH3/He (10%) at a rate of 30 mL/min. The TPD profile was obtained in the temperature range of 373–1073 K under the flow of He (99.999%). The solid state 31P NMR was carried out on JEOL ECZR 600 MHz spectrometer. A fast MAS of 20 KHz spinning speed with a 3.2 nm rotor was used to cover nuclei in the range of 31P. The FTIR analysis was done by using Perkin Elmer GX spectrophotometer. The spectra were taken in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 using KBr pellet. The Weisz-Prater criterion ( C W P ) and Mears criterion ( C M ) were used for the calculation of internal and external mass transfer limitations, are given below. If C W P < 1 and C M < 0.15 then internal and external mass transfer effect can be avoided (Section S3). (i) C W P = - r ' A o b s ρ c R 2 D e C A S (ii) C M = − r ' A ρ b Rn k c C A B 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The isopropanol dehydration reaction has been chosen as a probe reaction, whose decomposition either leads to the formation of propylene and di-isopropyl ether through dehydration on strong acidic sites or the formation of dehydrogenated product, acetone through the involvement of acid -base or redox sites [36,40,41]. Here the catalytic activity has been evaluated over fNP13 catalyst (1Nb: 3P: 0.5CTAB), which was thermally stable and showed its best performance in cyclohexanol dehydration reaction [39]. The reaction condition has been optimized by varying different parameters such as reaction temperature, WHSV and pretreatment temperature (Section S2). In order to obtain the optimum temperature, the catalytic activity was evaluated in a wide range of temperature (453–593 K) at atmospheric pressure with almost constant space velocity using fNP13 catalyst. It was found that the conversion of isopropanol is 21% at 453 K then tended to rise linearly with temperature and reached a maximum (71%) at 533 K (Table S2.). It is a well-known fact that the dehydration of alcohol is an endothermic reaction, so increase in reaction temperature shifted the equilibrium more towards formation of the product. However, at high temperature (573 K) the propylene adsorption and the generation of lighter olefin by thermal cracking may occur which lowers the conversion up to 64%. This result suggests that the optimum temperature for the isopropanol dehydration is 533 K over fNP13. 3.2 Calculation of activation energy The activation energy is one of the most important parameters of a chemical reaction and it is temperature sensitive. To calculate the activation energy, isopropanol dehydration reactions were carried out in a range of temperature (453–533 K) (Section S2). For the calculation, we have assumed that isopropanol dehydration followed first-order reaction kinetics in absence of mass transfer diffusion [42,43]. The calculated value of Weisz-Prater ( C W P ) and Mears ( C M ) Criterion are 4.93 × 10−1 <1 and 3.28578 × 10-6 respectively, which indicate that there is not any internal and external mass transfer limitation (Section S3). The first order rate constants Ke and Ke' in terms of catalyst packing volume and acidity are defined as follow. X is the catalytic conversion in steady state. (iv) K e ' = - v g A c w c l n ( 1 - X ) The activation energy for this reaction was 30 ± 5 kJ/mol, determined from rate constant (Eq. iv) in terms of acidity, using temperature dependence Arrhenius equation (Fig. 1 (a)). In the context of activation energy, our catalyst gives better result compared to reported catalysts (Table 1 ). Thus, fNP13 pretreated at 673 K, is the preferable catalyst in terms of catalytic performance at 533 K with a WHSV 4.7 h−1. Though there is fast deactivation, this catalyst shows superior space time yield (0.04 mol h−1 gcat −1) compared to previously reported catalysts (Table 2 ). 3.3 Regeneration study Regeneration and reusability are the important features for the commercialization of a heterogeneous catalyst. To investigate the potential ability for reusing the spent uNP13 catalyst, we, therefore, treated it with N2 and O2 mixture at 623 K. Up to 6th successive cycles, this catalyst showed satisfactory results with a slight variation of conversion (Fig. 2 ). This variation is mainly due to the incomplete removal of coke during regeneration, confirmed by FTIR, which may have masked the active sites. Indeed, uNP13 catalyst shows >99% selectivity after 6th run. This observation also concluded that high thermal stability (Fig. 6) is another prominent factor to retain the activity in each regenerative cycle. 3.4 Physicochemical characterization fNP13 catalyst shows a very high conversion (71%) up to 2 h of reaction then conversion starts decreasing and finally reaches 54% at 4 h time period keeping the selectivity constant (>99%) (Section S2). This type of rapid deactivation may have taken place either by the coke deposition as well as the structural changes of the fullerene-containing catalyst. To investigate the proper reason behind the deactivation, we have done several characterizations of used along with regenerated catalysts and compared them with a fresh one. Fig. 3 (a) shows the different characteristic vibrations of fresh, used and regenerated catalysts in FTIR spectra. Most of them are common and assigned previously [39]. The two bands were obtained at around 1240 cm−1 and 1060 cm−1, for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the phosphate species. Another strong band was appeared at 600-700 cm-1 related to Nb-O-Nb stretching modes. Whereas a band associated to niobyl species (Nb = O) appeared at 950 cm−1. This spectrum consistent with the previously reported niobium phosphate for alkylation reaction [50]. one new band arises at around 1400 cm−1 for uNP13 catalyst which may be due to the skeleton vibration of aliphatic −CH, −CH2, −CH3 group [39,51]. The band at 1623 cm−1 is assigned to the CTA moiety (as CTAB is used surfactant for synthesis). If we compare the intensity of each peak of all three catalysts, then we can see the significant decrease in peak intensity as well as absorbance area of used (uNP13) catalyst compared to fresh (fNP13) and regenerated catalysts (Fig. 3 (b)). This is due to the surface coverage by coke which causes deactivation. Apparently, it is expected that the catalyst deactivation is responsible for both carbon deposition and structural- textural decomposition. The morphology of the three catalysts is shown in Fig. S1 where stacked nanopetals features of fNP13 catalyst can be distorted after reaction and also covered by the carbon-rich species. Whereas after regeneration, carbons are more or less removed and some sort of flower-like morphology was retained. However, EDAX (Table 3 ) results show there was no significant leaching of the catalyst because nP/nNb atomic ratio was more or less same for all three catalysts. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of fresh, used and regenerated catalysts are shown type-II isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop, according to IUPAC convention, investigated by Kruk and Jaroniec (Fig. 4 (a)) [52,53]. The appearance of H3 hysteresis confirms the formation of slit-like pores by the aggregation of plate-like particles. The bimodal pore size distribution plot (Fig. 4(b)) of fNP13 catalyst confirmed the existence of small pores (4–5 nm) inside the nanopetals while relatively large pores (7–10 nm) associated within the stacked nanopetals [54]. These two different types of pores are responsible for enhancing the diffusion property within the flower like hierarchical structure, where mesopores are linked to small pores or to the external surface. By comparing porosity of fNP13 catalyst with uNP13, we can see that the BET surface area of the used catalyst is slightly higher than that of fresh catalyst and there is also a great enhancement of mesopore volume, while a slight decrease in microporous volume has also been observed (Table 3). This enhancement is probably due to the activation of new pores or widening of pre-existence pores (Fig. 4 (b)). This pore opening may be due to the removal of surfactant during the reaction. Generally, solvent washing is a key step for the preparation of catalyst via surfactant assisted route and it is a preliminary process for the easy removal of surfactant before it is fully removed by the calcination [55–58]. But in our process, neither we perform the solvent washing nor the surfactant being fully removed by calcination. So, during dehydration reaction, some amount of surfactant gets removed in aqueous alcohol environment. This causes the creation of new mesopores or broadening of narrow pores. The decrease in micropore volume may be ascribed as the pore blocking phenomena caused by the deposition of soft carbon species (Scheme 1 ). HRTEM micrographs are carried out in order to check the effect of reaction condition on morphology of fresh, used and regenerated catalysts. It is noted in Fig. 5 , the fNP13 catalyst having particles with irregular shape. A distinct and different morphology has been observed for uNP13 catalyst, where the particle size of uNP13 catalyst became larger than both fresh and regenerated catalysts respectively. This might be due to the agglomerations of particles as observed from the particle size distribution, which eventually responsible for catalyst deactivation. These particle agglomerations seem to happen during reaction and also responsible for deactivation. Whereas regenerated (rNP13) catalyst showed similar particle morphology as that of fNP13 catalyst. However, the coke present on used catalyst was not observed from TEM, this may be due to the amorphous nature of deposited carbon [59]. The TGA profiles of aforementioned catalyst are shown in Fig. 6. From the nonlinear curve, one can infer that there are mainly four mass changes in the temperature region 303–1073 K and these changes are particularly for the combustion of carbon in presence of air. The mass loss below 423 K, corresponds to the removal of physiosorbed water molecules, which is quite similar for each catalyst [51,60]. Further mass loss in the region of 423–573 K and 573–728 K for fNP13 and rNP13 catalysts is almost same which may be due to the combustion of surfactant (CTA) molecules present on the surface of the catalyst [55]. However, the mass loss in used (uNP13) catalyst is comparatively higher, which may be attributed to the combustion of surfactant along deposited soft coke. This verifies our assumption of deposition of coke during catalytic process. Furthermore, the sharp mass loss beyond 728 K is caused by the fullerene decomposition [61]. The O2-TPO profiles of the three catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 7 . The peaks observed within the temperature of 373–1073 K are attributed to the removal of carbon in the form of CO2. The equal quantity of O2 consumed for fNP13 and rNP13 catalysts in the temperature range of 385–675 K can be assigned due to the combustion of surfactant (CTA) molecules. On the other hand, a greater extent of O2 consumption for uNP13 indicates the oxidation of surfactant as well as of the deposited coke. This finding also connected with the second and third weight loss in TGA. Another peak located in the temperature region 690–1073 K, where O2 consumption follows the order of uNP13> rNP13> fNP13. This lower uptake of O2 for fNP13 catalyst corresponds to the combustion of fullerene carbon. Whereas the higher uptake for uNP13 catalyst is due to the burning of condensed coke along with fullerene carbon [60]. Generally, this type of heavy coke is formed on the acid sites and very difficult to remove from catalyst surface via oxidation [62]. That is why rNP13 catalyst shows higher O2 consumption than fNP13 but lower than uNP13 catalyst. The UV–vis absorption spectra of the catalysts have been displayed in Fig. 8 . The fNP13 catalyst showed a maximum absorption at around 230 nm, whereas uNP13 and rNP13 displayed a shift at higher wavelength (263 nm). Both absorption bands can be assigned for the charge transfer of oxygen to niobium atom [63]. This suggests that the niobium atoms are present either in penta or tetra coordinated environment. However, fNP13 catalyst exhibits another broad absorption band at 411 nm (Fig. 8 inset), associated with π→π* transition of C60 [64]. But a bathochromic shift was observed for both uNP13 and rNP13 catalysts at 443 and 481 nm respectively (inset image). This bathochromic shift of rNP13 catalyst is may be due to the oxidation of fullerene in presence of oxygen atmosphere during regeneration. Creegan et al. also observed a similar absorption maxima at around 493 nm for C60O [65]. Therefore, it can be said from UV–vis spectra that the reaction conditions have significant effect for changing its chemical property. The results from XRD analysis are shown in Fig. 9 (a). The characteristic fullerene phase was observed for used and regenerated catalysts as a prime phase at the same 2θ value as that of fresh catalyst. The peak broadening and decreasing of peak intensity suggested that the structure is not preserved after reaction and regeneration of the catalyst. It was noticed from the enlarged view (Fig. 9 (b)) that XRD peak of uNP13 catalyst became broader and shifted the maxima to the lower angles compared to the others, which implies lowering the crystallinity of the catalyst. This notable shifting is may be due to the deposition of amorphous carbon. In addition, the apparent decrease in fullerene peak intensity after regeneration may be caused either by the partial oxidation or the decomposition of fullerene. Aksenova et al. studied oxidation/decomposition behavior of fullerene under oxidative atmosphere at a temperature range of 673–773 K [66]. Thus, the XRD patterns qualitatively supported the UV–vis results. From the NH3-TPD analysis, it has been observed (Fig. 10 (b)) that the total acidic site concentration of regenerated catalyst does not differ significantly from that of fresh catalysts. Whereas greater changes have been observed for used catalyst after the reaction. This unexpected increase in total acidity may be due to the increase in surface area and the widening of the narrow pores (8–9 nm), causes the probe gas (NH3) to be easily accessible to the acid sites situated inside the broad pores. During regeneration in presence of oxygen, fullerene may be oxidized to form an epoxide which is more basic in nature. Thus, coke deposition and regeneration by oxygen both have the beneficial role of tuning the acidity of the fNP13 catalyst. To explore phosphorous environment, CP-MAS 31P NMR are carried out for fresh spent as well as regenerated catalyst and depicted in Fig. 11 . The persistence of signal for fNP13 catalyst with a chemical shift of -2 ppm and-3 ppm are similar but inequivalent phosphorous atoms [67]. These peaks also hinted that two molecules of template are attached with phosphorous in tetrahedron environment by the interaction of P-O− and CTA + molecule [67,68]. On the other hand, two additional signals centered at – 10.5 and -26.5 ppm are observed which may due to the existence of surface (H2PO4)− and PO4 3- species [22,24]. However, a small downfield shift for uNP13 catalyst from -2.049 ppm to -0.017 ppm may be attributed to the removal of surfactant during reaction [68]. Adsorption of water during dehydration reaction is another reason behind the shifting of signal in downfield which is also reported by Sayari et al. and jones et. al. [67,69]. A broad peak in the region of -10.5 to -30 ppm is probably due to the overlapping of several signal. Though the broad signal does not indicate specific phosphorous environment but confirms the presence of mixed phosphorous species (H2PO4 −, HPO4 −2, PO4 3−). A comparison of all three spectra in the same range indicates the highest signal broadening for used catalyst as due to the rich in hydrogen phosphate groups (H2PO4 −, HPO4 −2) on used surface, which also approved the source of strong acid sites and this result compatible with NH3-TPD. During the reaction, the positively charged surfactant vacates the phosphate group from surfactant phosphoric acid complex. Hence, the phosphate group becomes free which contributed to the total acidity by increasing the population of hydrogen phosphate species. So, different phosphorous species can act as potential acidity controller. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have prepared and tested fullerene containing niobium phosphate catalyst for isopropanol dehydration. The as-synthesized catalyst so far faces deactivation but still shows effective conversion and >99% selectivity. Since intermolecular dehydration reaction for the selective production of propylene needs small pore as compare to di-isopropyl ether which requires larger pores for carrying out its intramolecular dehydration reaction. That’s why the increasing mesopore volume and acidity during reaction cannot stop the deactivation. The activation energy and space time yield both are superior to other reported catalysts which may be due to the absence of internal and external mass transfer limitations. Several techniques were employed to study the structural and textural integrity of the fresh, used and regenerated catalysts. Complementary FTIR, TGA, O2-TPO, BET analysis recommended the formation of coke on the uNP13 catalyst surface, leading to the blocking of micropores. The accumulation of carbon rich species on the catalyst surface after reaction causes distortion of flower-like morphology. Microstructural analysis admits the particle arrangement of uNP13 differs from that of fNP13 and rNP13 catalysts. NH3-TPD results showed the unusual acidity order of uNP13> rNP13> fNP13. The higher acidity of uNP13 is may be due to broadening of mesopores. Whereas fullerene oxidation during regeneration of used catalyst is the reason behind further decrease in its acidity. The release of surfactant from surfactant phosphoric acid complex leads to increase in hydrogen phosphate species, obtained in CP-MAS 31P NMR. Thus, it can be inferred that the reaction condition plays crucial role for controlling physicochemical properties of the fullerene containing niobium phosphate catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis of lower olefins from biomass is an attractive area of research as the petroleum feedstocks are limited day to day. A fullerene [C60] based niobium phosphate acid catalyst has been tested for isopropanol dehydration in gas phase for production of propylene and a thorough study has been undertaken on its recyclability. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst before and after reaction have been studied by several techniques, namely FTIR, FESEM, BET surface area, HRTEM, NH3-TPD, TGA, XRD and O2-TPO. The BET result suggests the trapping of coke within the micropores which retard the catalytic activity. Interestingly, the NH3-TPD profile demonstrates the abrupt increase in acidity of the used catalyst due to the widening of narrow pores while, CP-MAS 31 P NMR spectra show increase in population of hydrogen phosphate species may be caused by the decomposition of surfactant phosphoric acid complex. However, the UV–vis spectra support structural change by the oxidation of fullerene during regeneration leads to decrease in the acidity. The catalytic activity is evaluated in the temperature range 453–573 K, shows consistent performance up to 6th regenerated cycle with low activation energy (30 ± 5 kJ/mol). Furthermore, a detailed discussion of the reaction kinetics and reaction mechanism has also been demonstrated.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydration of isopropanol to propylene over fullerene[C60] containing niobium phosphate catalyst: Study on catalyst recyclability
